experience.description: As a Computational Plasma Physics Intern at IPP Greifswald, I supported research in plasma physics by developing and optimizing computational tools. My work included writing routines to calculate plasma distances to the divertor target, cleaning and improving existing code from research professors, and collaborating on projects involving the xemc3 library for magnetic field line tracing and analysis.
experience.company_name: Max Planck Institute for Plasma Physics

education_degrees: Bachelor of Science - BSc., Computer Science

Iâ€™m excited to share that I recently participated in my very first GCPC (German Collegiate Programming Contest), where our team placed 3rd at TUM and ranked 14th nationwide across Germany! ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡ªğŸ’»

But what mattered even more: we had an amazing time ğŸ¤©
What began with a simple message from me, looking for teammates, turned into one of the best team experiences Iâ€™ve ever had. Dominik M. Weber , Jonas Jacob Biermann For five intense hours, we solved problems, debugged code, exchanged ideas, and pushed through challenges together.
The moments when we saw the green light flash on our submissions were pure joy. ğŸš¦

Iâ€™m incredibly proud of what we achieved as a team and grateful for the synergy we built. Everyone brought their strengths to the table and Iâ€™m glad that my mathematical background could contribute meaningfully.

Competitions like this arenâ€™t just about coding. Theyâ€™re about teamwork, resilience, communication, and trust. Skills that matter far beyond the world of algorithms.

Looking forward to more contests and challenges like this! ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’»âœ¨

On to the next one! Incredible weekend at the Center for Digital Technology and Management (CDTM) Hackathon in Munich! 

The Center for Digital Technology and Management (CDTM) Hackathon in Munich, hosted at the Celonis office was an unforgettable experience. I had the privilege of hearing wonderful panels from industry leaders like Thomas Pischke from Trade Republic and Pedro Pereira from Celonis . Additionally, being surrounded by talented builders and developers also created an incredible atmosphere over the weekend.

My team and I, Marcos Ramirez Joos , Amar Ribic , Jonas Jacob Biermann , took on the avi challenge. Optimise the process of new client intake at medical hospitals and clinics. Basically, making the process of new client arriving to understanding the patient and his medical history more efficient. How did we do this?

We built 2 solutions. One for the patient, another for the doctor. Our patient onboarding had easy and accessible steps for uploading the userâ€™s medical data. The patient could then have a ğ—»ğ—®ğ˜ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—¹ ğ˜ƒğ—¼ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—² ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» with an AI Agent regarding his pain and automatically book an appointment. 

For doctors, we built an intuitive UI, where he could easily view his patients. Our magic touch: adding an ğ—”ğ—œ ğ—°ğ—µğ—®ğ˜ for each patient. We integrated a fully immersive AI chat so that the doctor could quickly extract necessary context for his upcoming patients. Additionally, we displayed key information from each patient. 

I would love to give a huge thank you to Center for Digital Technology and Management (CDTM) and Celonis for such an incredible weekend. Also to all the companies avi , Trade Republic and Beam AI for the exciting cases, as well as all the organisers and the CDTM crew for all the help over the weekend. It was soo much fun participating and I am already looking forward to the next one! #cdtmhacks #medtech

This weekend Amar Ribic , Troy R. and I formed a team to compete at TUM.ai Makeathon. We decided to tackle the challenge set by CHECK24 Vergleichsportal GmbH : Building an AI based Hotel Recommendation Engine enabling users to interact with hotel search by using natural language only.

With our algorithm and final pitch, we managed to convince the jury and were awarded 2nd place among 23 competing teams!

Huge thanks to TUM.ai for organising this amazing event and the great CHECK24 Vergleichsportal GmbH team for their support and guidance throughout the hackathon.

On the first day of the Hannover Messe, Cem Ã–zdemir, the German Federal Minister of Research, visited our stand. Humberto Trimino Mora , a scientist at IPP, explained the principle of Wendelstein 7-X to him and provided information about the state of fusion research.

In general, the topic of nuclear fusion was met with great interest by visitors to the trade fair.

If you would like to come by, we will be in Hall 2, Stand A28 (joint stand of the BMBF, the Bundesministerium fÃ¼r Bildung und Forschung ) until Friday.

Photo: BMBF/Hans-Joachim Rickel #fusionenergy #nuclearfusion

A love letter to Munich. ğŸ’Œ 

Thereâ€™s a quiet revival happening in Europe, and itâ€™s taking the shape of machines.

That might sound odd in a world that has spent the past decade convincing itself that everything important happens in software. For years, we were told that code would eat the world. And yet, walking through Munich (or Garching if you want the symbolism) today, it feels like the world is starting to eat code back.

Two years ago, when we led a â‚¬20M seed round in a company called Proxima Fusion it, nominally, seemed to be an investment into fusion. But to call it that would be like describing the moon landing as a good use of kerosene. 

It was, more precisely, a belief that Europe hadnâ€™t forgotten to build what matters. Not in apps. Not in abstractions. But in people who still bend metal, build machines, and dare to alter physics. 

At the time, it felt almost contrarian to believe that this continent, with its long winters and cautious investors, could still produce the kind of ambition that once powered its industrial age. But now, that belief is starting to look less naÃ¯ve.

Munich is in the proof. TUM, LMU, and Max Planck students are quietly dropping out of academia to found companies instead of publishing papers. Siemens, BMW, and Airbus supply the industrial gravity. Something is shifting here and it feels less like Berlin in 2018 and more like Palo Alto in 1968. 

This is what happens when engineers start dreaming again.

You see it everywhere:
- Proxima Fusion - building machines that could give humanity infinite clean energy.
- Helsing - creating AI that defends democracies.
- The Exploration Company - bringing back the spirit of European spaceflight.
- Isar Aerospace - building rockets to enable access.
- Quantum Systems - fusing hardware, autonomy, and defense.
- Hades Mining , Alpine Eagle , Manex AI , microagi , OSM , CedarDB , Neoways , CoBrowser - each proof that Europe is rediscovering its taste for hard problems.

... and they donâ€™t behave like European startups. They behave like global companies that happen to be European.

At redalpine , weâ€™ve been betting on this intersection - software meeting science - for nearly two decades. When we started, there wasnâ€™t even a word for it. Now itâ€™s called â€œDeepTech,â€ though whatâ€™s really happening is that the boundary between science and entrepreneurship is dissolving. 

And that, I think, is the quiet truth beneath all this noise about Europe â€œcatching up.â€ Europe doesnâ€™t need to become Silicon Valley. It just needs to remember what it once was. 

If a next generation of global companies is born here, it will likely be in places like Munich and Zurich, built on a culture that still believes in precision, iteration, and patience - things Silicon Valley forgot when it traded atoms for ads.

If youâ€™re building at that intersection - letâ€™s talk. ğŸ¤˜

A Month Full of Experiences, Knowledge, and New Perspectives: Poland Study Academy by the Hans-BÃ¶ckler-Stiftung I left home and what was familiar for a month and returned with a â€œsuitcaseâ€ full of experiences and insights into Polish language, politics, history, and culture.

When I applied for this international academy of the Hans BÃ¶ckler Foundation, I did not expect how profoundly this time would shape me.

ğŸ”¸ Language Course at Jagiellonian University Every morning, I attended language classes.  I can now proudly say: MÃ³wiÄ™ trochÄ™ po polsku (I speak a little Polish).

ğŸ”¸ Politics & History
One of the highlights was the lecture series by Dr. Piotr Horbatowski on the Round Table talks, the SolidarnoÅ›Ä‡ movement, and the transition from communism to democracy. We also went on numerous excursions: to Nowa Huta, a district created under the Six-Year Plan of the communists, visits to old factories, shelters, and conversations with the Solidarity trade union.

ğŸ”¸ KrakÃ³w â€“ a City of Many Facets
KrakÃ³w revealed itself to us from different angles: from the historic old town with its churches, castles, and art, to the Jewish quarter, the former ghetto, and Schindlerâ€™s Factory. Each tour opened up new perspectives.

ğŸ”¸ Auschwitz â€“ an Experience That Leaves a Mark
What moved me most deeply was the visit to Auschwitz. Despite all I had already learned through books, documentaries, workshops, and my own engagement against antisemitism, I could not hold back my tears. Standing in those rooms, seeing those images, makes you grasp the sheer magnitude of horror in a way nothing else can. It leaves you with a deep sense of responsibility: to make sure that such suffering never happens again.

This study academy was far more than just an exchange program. It was an intense learning journey that enriched me with new language skills, deeper historical understanding, and invaluable encounters.

ğŸ™ğŸ» A heartfelt thank you to the Hans BÃ¶ckler Foundation for making this unforgettable experience possible.

If your idea of a good time includes tweaking RÂ² at 3 a.m., this is for you. ğŸ¤“ 
We launched the Wunder RNN Challenge for those who train neural networks at work, after work, and sometimes instead of work (+weekends). 

Youâ€™re invited to create a model that predicts the next market state from a sequence of previous states.

â†’ Timeline: September 15 â€” December 1
â†’ Prize pool: $13,600 USDT

This is the kind of challenge quants face every day. The dataset contains anonymized market features from our live trading. No domain knowledge is required â€” just strong modeling skills.

Winners will get cash prizes, a fast-track to Wunder Fund, and most importantly, the wunder-ful intellectual thrill of solving hard problems.

â†’ Get the data and compete at https://wundernn.io
